title: In Cowboys' loss to Packers, Kellen Moore revealed strength that excited Jason Witten
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Week 5 had revenge games and shocking upsets. Lorenzo Reyes delivers this weeks power rankings and biggest risers and fallers. USA TODAY

In the postgame locker room after the New Orleans Saints beat the Cowboys 12-0, tight end Jason Witten was frustrated.

Not only had a previously strong Dallas offense sputtered, but Witten also had fumbled for just the ninth time in his then-243 career games.

“It’s the worst feeling in the world,” Witten told USA TODAY Sports. “You feel like you let the whole team down, the whole organization down.”

He told reporters: “Next Sunday can’t get here fast enough.”

Then the Cowboys fell 34-24 to the Green Bay Packers. Aaron Rodgers notched his seventh win against the Cowboys in the last eight contests, with Witten suiting up for each of those losses, including two playoff eliminations. In Sunday’s defeat, the Cowboys trailed 31-3 in the third quarter.

It was hardly the cathartic comeback game Witten sought after coming up short against the Saints. And yet, his takeaway from Dallas’ second consecutive loss wasn’t discouragement.

“I’m excited, kind of got a pep in my step for this week to be here,” Witten told USA TODAY Sports on Tuesday, speaking in conjunction with Dr. Teal’s Epsom Salt Soaks. “These last two games have been tough, but I feel like I’m here for a reason. And part of that is in times like this. When the team is 3-2 and they’re looking around, it’s a great opportunity for me.”

The chance to show leadership as a 16-year pro is one source of Witten’s excitement for this week. But he also draws solace from the Cowboys’ third- and fourth-quarter comeback run. Sure, they needed to ramp up production while curtailing turnovers in the first three quarters. Quarterback Dak Prescott’s three interceptions and Brett Maher’s two missed field goals stifled too many promising drives. But gaining 200 yards from the time 19 seconds remained in the third quarter was a significant achievement. So, too, were the 13 first downs and 21 points tallied in the fourth.

Witten credits first-year offensive coordinator Kellen Moore for smart in-game adjustments.

“I think one of the areas he really shines is in game,” Witten said. “His ability to make adjustments, see what they’re doing and then countering that. It showed up in the Green Bay game.”

When the Packers stuck to man coverage despite their sizable third-quarter lead, Moore queued up plays for star receiver Amari Cooper, who powered double moves to a career-high 226 receiving yards. When Packers cornerback Tramon Williams shadowed receiver Michael Gallup tightly late in the third quarter, Moore and Prescott didn’t hesitate to trust him on a go route on second-and-4. Gallup muscled the ball away from Williams and powered through cornerback Josh Jackson’s leaping tackle to earn a 40-yard touchdown.

Decisions like that, Witten said, will pay dividends later in the season.

“[Moore] kept adjusting to what they were doing,” Witten said. “And down the stretch, when you play against the best teams, the ability to adjust as a playcaller and as players in game and say, ‘Yeah, OK, our film study said this, but we’re seeing something different?’ That’s the chess match.

“I think Kellen’s got a really good feel in how he communicates, how he adjusts to that in game that’s allowing him to be as successful as he is.”

POWER RANKINGS: New teams enter top 10 following losses by Cowboys, Chargers

MORE: What happened to the Cowboys' run D vs. Packers?

Witten is confident the Cowboys can rebound from their recent skid. He’s excited to continue contributing in both the blocking and pass-catching phases, where he’s snagged 17 of 20 targets for 173 yards and two touchdowns after a year-long retirement in 2018.

The 37-year-old says his body actually feels better so far after a year away from football’s toll, as he fastidiously sticks to muscle recovery regiments like Dr. Teal’s Epsom salts. Through five games, “I’ve never felt like I couldn’t go out there and do the things I did 10 years ago,” Witten said.

He sees promise in younger teammates, too.

Just as Witten bounced back from the low of his New Orleans interception, he has no qualms that Prescott will move past the three interceptions he threw in a 463-yard, two-touchdown performance. Prescott, Witten said, will be ready for Dallas’ next two contests against the Jets and Eagles.

“He’s not one of those guys you have to worry about from that standpoint of you’ve got to keep his confidence high or spirit the right way,” Witten said. “really it’s just kind of a high five, show some energy to him, give him some love and move on to the next game.

“He’s as poised as any teammate I’ve ever had.”

Follow Jori Epstein on Twitter @JoriEpstein.

If you love talking football, we have the perfect spot for you. Join our Facebook Group, The Ruling Off the Field, to engage in friendly debate and conversation with fellow football fans and our NFL insiders.
description: Even though the Cowboys are coming off consecutive losses, 37-year-old tight end Jason Witten feels invigorated by where the team stands now.
